stem: A 32-year-old client with bipolar disorder is admitted after their sertraline (SSRI) dose was doubled while taking lithium. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, two actions the nurse should take, and two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute CNS irritability and autonomic storm.
Background: Stable on lithium. Recent increase in sertraline to 200mg.
Assessment: Client is diaphoretic, agitated, and experiencing uncontrollable leg jerking. BP 182/104.
Recommendation: Immediately discontinue all serotonergic agents.

actionOptions.text: Administer IV benzodiazepines (e.g., diazepam) to control rigidity.
Instruct the client to perform muscle exercises to stop the clonus.

parameterOptions.text: Core temperature and presence of inducible clonus.
Neurological status and heart rate (autonomic stability).
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose.

rationale.correct: The client is experiencing serotonin syndrome (c2). Lithium potentiates serotonin, and when combined with a high-dose SSRI (sertraline), it can trigger a life-threatening autonomic crisis. Key signs are hyperreflexia, clonus, hyperthermia (103.2째F/39.6째C), and mydriasis. Priority actions include stopping the serotonergic drugs (a1) and administering benzodiazepines (a2) to reduce body temperature and muscle rigidity. Monitoring should focus on temperature/clonus (p1) and autonomic stability (p2).
clinicalPearls: Serotonin syndrome is characterized by hyperreflexia and clonus (shaking legs).
Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS) presents similarly but features 'lead-pipe' rigidity (no clonus).
Cyproheptadine is the specific antidote for serotonin syndrome if benzodiazepines are ineffective.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking this is solely lithium toxicity.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: While the lithium level is high-therapeutic (1.4 mEq/L), the patient's fever, jerking legs, and autonomic instability indicate a drug interaction. Consider the recent SSRI dose increase.

mnemonic.title: S-H-I-V-E-R
mnemonic.expansion: S-Sweating, H-Hyperreflexia/Clonus, I-Increased Temperature, V-Vital Sign Instability, E-Encephalopathy, R-Restlessness
